title: 105_hr2997
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fairness in the Workplace Commission Act". The Congress finds that workers are not seeing wage and benefit increases proportional to corporate profits, with a widening wage gap between men and women. Despite progress in closing the education gap, wage disparities persist among minority groups, leading to increased job insecurity due to corporate downsizing and deregulation. The last decade has seen a growth in the use of part-time and temporary workers, with insufficient research done on the extent and impact of this trend. Wage disparities persist, especially for female workers, as wages fail to keep pace with economic growth and corporate profits. The National Commission on Fairness in the Workplace is established by the Act, with members authorized to take actions on behalf of the Commission. The Chairperson is appointed by the President, and the Vice Chairperson is elected by the members. The Commission's term lasts for 18 months after the Act's enactment. The National Commission on Fairness in the Workplace will examine the growing corporate practice of providing lower wages and benefits to part-time and temporary employees compared to full-time employees. They will also investigate the impact of part-time and temporary employment on wage levels, job insecurity, and productivity. Additionally, the Commission will explore reasons for stagnant wages, the wage gap between men and women, and wage disparities among minority populations. The Commission will develop policy options for Congress to address problems identified in the examination regarding minority populations in various states and territories. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. Within 60 days of the enactment of this Act, the Commission will consist of 14 members appointed by the President, Majority Leader of the Senate, Minority Leader of the Senate, Speaker of the House of Representatives, and Minority Leader of the House. Members will come from the executive branch, labor, business management, academia, Senate, House of Representatives, and private life. The Commission will consist of 14 members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of Labor. Members will come from different sectors and will be appointed for life. They will be paid based on the rate of basic pay for GS-15. Appointments can be made without regard to certain limitations. Members of the Commission, including federal employees, cannot receive extra compensation. They will receive travel expenses as per regulations. The Commission has general authority as outlined in Section 6. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, meetings, appoint staff, and procure services as needed. Meetings are scheduled monthly or as called by the chairperson or majority members. The Commission can also request staff from Federal agencies. The Commission has the authority to obtain personnel from Federal agencies, secure information directly from government departments, contract for research services, use the United States mails, and request administrative support services as needed. The Commission can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. It also has the power to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to its investigations within the United States. It has the power to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to its investigations within the United States. If a person fails to obey a subpoena, the Commission can apply to a court for an order to compel testimony or evidence, with failure to comply punishable as civil contempt. Subpoenas must be served according to the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. The application under paragraph (2) can be served in the judicial district where the person resides or can be found. The Commission will report its findings, policy options, and recommendations to Congress within 30 days after its termination date.
